The number of people facing insufficient food consumption spiked sharply after the pivotal events of August 2021. Since then, some nine in ten households have faced insufficient food consumption each month. See the IPC for overall food security.

Food consumption is even worse than when COVID-19 first struck the country. Insufficient food consumption had already spiked to 75 percent in August 2020, at the first peak of the pandemic. But when this couldn’t seem to have gotten worse, a combination of drought, conflict, political instability, and the economic crisis collided to deepen the food security crisis. By August 2022, Afghanistan had topped the list of countries with insufficient food consumption. It has remained there since.

One-fifth (22 percent) of the population is food insecure - an improvement from 29 percent reported in July. These improvements were unequal; low-income households saw food security indicators worsen (at 42 percent food insecure).

Food insecurity in Fiji has worsened to 59 percent, from 43 percent in end-2021. While Vanuatu has the highest food insecurity (68 percent), this is an improvement against the 74 percent in end-2021. Kiribati’s figures have remained stable in recent quarters.

*Findings for the Pacific are available regularly through the dashboard, rather than a report.

Around one-fifth (21 percent) of the population is food insecure (more than 1.3 million people). Food insecurity is especially concentrated in certain regions, though the prevalence of food insecurity in rural and urban areas is similar. Trends are not yet available.

The first report is set to be finalized in late October/early November. Preliminary results indicate that 14 percent of the population is food insecure, and that there are substantial variations across different parts of the country. Trends are not yet available.

Around one-third of the population was food insecure in September (32 percent), amid the country’s worst economic crisis since its independence in 1948. July was an especially harsh month, with nearly half of the population food insecure. For a country in which food insecurity was at 9.1 percent in 2019,1 the shock of the current crisis is reverberating across all facets of life.

People are being forced to rely on coping strategies to keep food on the table. Around eight in ten households are regularly turning to food-based coping strategies such as sacrificing meals, borrowing food, and reducing the number of meals eaten. Diets are in a precarious state. Nearly four in ten households are facing insufficient food consumption, with many consuming far less diverse diets as food prices remain high across the country. The instability comes amid escalating anxieties about prices.
Latest findings are not ready yet.

The findings from the sixth round of the survey (June 2022) show that, nationally, food security conditions in Nepal have slightly improved compared to October 2021. Over one-tenth (13.2 percent) of the population had insufficient food consumption in June 2022. However, the continued increase in food prices (reflecting, in part, increased fuel prices and a weaking rupee) are impacting households across the country. Stakeholders are advised to continue monitoring the situation, as the depleted resilience of households, coupled with an economic downturn or less than average harvest, may place increased pressure on already vulnerable households and tip some borderline households into food insecurity.

Food security improved slightly compared to October 2021, but approximately 3.86 million people (13.2%) in Nepal were not consuming an adequate diet in June 2022. About 3 percent of households reported that they did not have enough food; among these 63.3 percent said that increasing prices of food was the main reason. Among all households, 78.2 percent listed increasing food prices as a main concern.

Nearly one-fifth (18 percent) of households in Tajikistan were food insecure in September. Compared to the assessment carried out in May, the proportion of food-insecure households has slightly improved, by 3 percentage points.

The first report is set to be finalized in late October/early November. Preliminary results indicate that one-third of the population (34 percent) is food insecure, and that there is high reliance on coping strategies.Trends are not yet available.
